BIOS325
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2026, starting with year 3.

Overview

Overview
This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure and dynamics of biodiversity and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis.

Teaching will be delivered in a series of two-week blocks that each cover a fundamental topic in ecology and introduce linked real-world problems whose solutions are grounded in ecology (30 contact hours). Each topic will be taught over two weeks, and will comprise, as a minimum, six hours of contact time including five research connected and interactive lectures and one discussion / debate or campus-based field teaching / computer lab. Many topics will have associated asynchronous material (lecture or active learning content) to broaden topic understanding and structure independent study.

Two module assessments (one of these groupwork) are designed to test:

(i) depth of understanding of key advanced topics in ecology,
(ii) critical evaluation of the role of ecology in providing solutions to environmental problems, and
(iii) the ability to synthesise, integrate and critically evaluate how both biological processes and concepts and factors from outside of ecology are linked to specified global environmental problems.
Educational Aims
• Provide students with an advanced understanding of biological diversity, its structure, dynamics and responses to environmental change.

• Develop in students an integrated and general understanding of the critical concepts and biological processes in ecology and their interplay with evolution, behaviour and organism form and function.

• Enable students to recognise global problems that have ecological dimensions and to understand how and to what extent ecology can contribute solutions to these issues.

• Develop in students the ability to critically evaluate and synthesise evidence within and beyond the field of ecology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
We are facing an ecological crisis that threatens biological diversity and undermines the life-support system—the many essential ecological goods and services—provided to us by nature. This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure of biodiversity, and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis. Content will be delivered via lectures, structured discussions and debates, and workshops and assessed by extended writing. Assessment will involve two assignments, the first based on critically evaluating the role of ecology in understanding and addressing global environmental problems and the second involving evaluation of how different biological concepts and processes (including those from within and beyond ecology) are relevant to particular global environmental problems.
Outline Syllabus
This module will build on teaching in ecology given in the first year (core modules and first year field course), and introduced through the Zoology Programme content delivered in year 2 semester 1. This module will cover five topics in advanced ecology. These will be selected from the following list depending on the availability of staff to teach them:

Topic 1: How do metapopulation structure and landscape configuration shape species’ responses to climate change?

Topic 2: The ecology of infectious disease: concepts and models to understand and control the spread of disease in natural populations of animals and plants

Topic 3: Macro-ecology and the global distribution of biodiversity

Topic 4: Functional ecology and environmental change: understanding how traits shape species’ ecological strategy, their responses to the environment and ecosystem processes and services

Topic 5: Understanding and predicting the impacts of invasive alien species

Topic 6: Ecological complexity and the maintenance of stable and sustainable ecosystems

Topic 7: Agro-ecology for sustainable and regenerative food production

Topic 8: Community genetics: the ecological consequences of intraspecific variation for community structure and ecosystem functioning

Each topic will be taxonomically broad and will include detail of ecological concepts, theory and mathematical principles relevant to a specific environmental issue or problem. The topics will also be supported by accompanying AO learning materials designed to increase the depth of coverage or briefly cover basic ecological background not elsewhere represented in the programme.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas

Students will be expected to engage fully with all contact-based and directed learning resources, but also engage in self-directed learning to broaden their understanding of the teaching material and to find published literature relevant to the topics and assignments that are not presented in the teaching materials themselves.

As required, students will need to prepare for discussion/ debate sessions and for groupwork through directed and independent learning (reading, asynchronous learning materials, independent study).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. In a typical week learning activities will be centred around lecture-based content, with asynchronous learning, debates, discussions or computer labs developing and extending the lecture-based content. In each two-week topic block there will be 5 hours of lectures, 1 hour of either structured discussion, debate or computer practical, 2-hours of unscheduled e-lectures or other structured self-learning tasks and 16 hours of self-directed learning. A further 14 hours self-directed learning and 16 hours group working will take place across two semester weeks associated with preparation for assessments.

Teaching methods: Lectures (25 hours)

Description: Interactive research-led lectures and seminars covering background and theory on key advanced topics in ecology and the relationships to current global environmental problems
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-outs discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A. Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Seminars (3 hours)

Description: Seminars will take the form of structured discussions and debates. Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics in ecology or topic-relevant ecological papers and reports, with a focus on developing skills in argument construction and critical analysis and synthesis of evidence
Each topic will provide at least one opportunity for students to gain experience in discussing advanced ecology in groups or individually, supported by preparation through reading/ asynchronous online learning tasks or data handling, building confidence in the students. Staff-led and student-led discussion will form the basis of these group sessions fostering critical thinking and confidence. The sessions will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore a greater breadth of issues, and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of different biological and non-biological factors influencing global environmental problems. Attendance will be monitored.
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Practical (2 hours)

Description: Computer workshops. Data manipulation/ modelling practicals designed to reinforce understanding of mathematical models that can be applied to understand and predict dynamic interactions within and between species
Computer workshops enhance digital fluency, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: E-lectures (unscheduled; 10 hours)

Description: Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material, learning tasks, or structured reading provided to broaden topic understanding and stimulate independent study
This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for contact sessions (lectures and discussions), and that adds value to independent study time, leading to a greater depth and breadth of learning. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. This material includes recommended reading (from texts and peer reviewed literature), structured reading (guided literature searching/ reading with specific goals linked to contact sessions), links to external video or web copy, theoretical background, reflection and critical assessment tasks based around lectures and discussions. (Confidence; Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement monitored in contact sessions.

Teaching methods: Group work (16 hours)

Description: Small group work to prepare and submit the integrative ecology assignment. Working in small groups is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches, and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Groupwork also promotes skills in team-based working and collaboration that are highly sought after in the workplace.
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement and contribution monitored through peer assessment.

Teaching methods: Self-directed learning (94 hours)

Description: Consolidation of taught material; preparation for taught sessions, discussions, debates and computer practicals; literature review, evaluation and synthesis to support taught sessions and assignments.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Two summative assessments (coursework), one in the middle of S1 and one at end of course:

i) Ecological solutions assignment (70% weighting): A critical evaluation of the role of ecology in understanding and addressing/ solving a specified major global environmental problem or issue (based on one of the module topics chosen each year by teaching staff; different topic each year). Students will review the state-of-the-art for the specified topic in ecology, drawing on teaching materials and independent study, and will discuss how it has informed our understanding of, and provided solutions for, a specific environmental problem. They will also critically evaluate the extent to which this ecological knowledge has made a real-world difference, and any limitations to progress arising from knowledge gaps.

ii) Integrative ecology assignment (30% weighting, groupwork). This assignment will challenge students to contrast, synthesise and critically evaluate learning from this module with relevant teaching content developed outside this module (e.g. relating to evolutionary biology, conservation biology, behaviour, physiology, organismal form and function etc). The assignment will be based on 3 of the topics/ environmental problems covered in the module. For each, the students will review, critically evaluate and synthesise how both ecological and non-ecological concepts and processes are relevant to shaping biotic responses to/ or the development of the environmental problem. The linked processes/ concepts could include any from evolution, behaviour, conservation, genetics, physiology, etc for which there is an evidence base, and to do this the students will need to draw on teaching/learning from this module, from common Y1 modules, from the pre-requisite module(s) and from their independent learning.

Both assignments are highly authentic and research-connected and reflect real-world problems to which an understanding of ecology can contribute strongly. The skills for completion are taught through active learning developed within discussion sessions and debates and through asynchronous online learning tasks and independent learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Both assignments emphasise higher level learning skills that are highly sought after by employers, including critical evaluation, problem solving, literature synthesis, conceptual synthesis, and emphasise digital fluency (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Although formal formative assessment will not be used in this module, the students will receive feedback on their understanding of the content from teaching staff and peers, through discussion sessions and debates and groupwork.

Assessment will take place on the CANVAS VLE for both assignments, using rubrics tailored from current standard rubrics for scientific reports. For the Integrative Ecology assignment, students will complete a Peer Assessment, which will be used to weight each student's marks by their contributions to the groupwork.

A Resit opportunity exists. Reassessment will use the same format but the topic (or topic set) or data will differ. In the case of the Integrative Ecology assignment, if there is only one resitting student, they will have the opportunity to review and discuss their plans for the assignment with one of the teaching team, to get feedback, to ensure they are not placed at a disadvantage, relative to a student group. Reassessment marks will be capped at 40%. Reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate how fundamental ecological concepts, processes and mathematical principles explain/shape the structure and dynamics of populations, communities and ecosystems, at a range of spatial and trophic scales.
 LO2 Critically analyse and synthesize the contributions that ecology makes to understanding, predicting and mitigating global environmental problems.
 LO3 Critically evaluate how different biological and non-biological factors and processes impinge on global environmental problems, using an evidence-based and integrative approach.
 LO4 Synthesise and critically evaluate a range of information, concepts and processes relevant to key ecological problems from this module, life sciences core teaching modules and pre-requisite modules.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed (i) through the use of evidence-based reasoning in classroom discussions and debates focussed on module topics, (ii) through critical evaluation of the uses of ecology in solving real-world problems and (iii) through reflection on the extent to which the literature reach consensus over optimal approaches to solve ecological problems (or indicate knowledge gaps).
 S2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions and debates, groupwork, and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 S3 Teamwork—This skill will be developed through preparation for discussion sessions in groups and for planning and carrying out the integrative ecology assignment (groupwork).
 S4 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their understanding of advanced ecological topics and the ways in which peer discussion/ debate alters this and ii) feedback given during discussion sessions and following AO learning tasks as appropriate.
 S5 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed using data-based learning activities and computer labs (for any topic that requires this).
 S6 Evidence based reasoning—This will be developed in students first through discussion and debate seminars (and linked AO learning tasks) and subsequently through evidence synthesis and critical evaluation of the use of advanced ecology to solve global environmental problems.
 S7 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through an advanced understanding of the ways in which ecology can be used to solve environmental problems and the review and critical evaluation of this application of ecological theory.
 S8 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the module topics for discussions, debates, learning tasks and assignments. This skill will be evident (and assessed) through assignments.
 S9 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the (i) the need to efficiently review and synthesise areas of the scientific literature using online databases (ii) through the handling and analysis of data for topics requiring data-based asynchronous learning tasks, and using software to create diagrams to communicate conceptual or review-based information.
 S10 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be fostered through assignments that require the review, critical evaluation and synthesis of information from the ecological literature and related relevant fields.

New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2026, starting with year 3.

Overview

Overview
This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure and dynamics of biodiversity and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis.

Teaching will be delivered in a series of two-week blocks that each cover a fundamental topic in ecology and introduce linked real-world problems whose solutions are grounded in ecology (30 contact hours). Each topic will be taught over two weeks, and will comprise, as a minimum, six hours of contact time including five research connected and interactive lectures and one discussion / debate or campus-based field teaching / computer lab. Many topics will have associated asynchronous material (lecture or active learning content) to broaden topic understanding and structure independent study.

Two module assessments (one of these groupwork) are designed to test:

(i) depth of understanding of key advanced topics in ecology,
(ii) critical evaluation of the role of ecology in providing solutions to environmental problems, and
(iii) the ability to synthesise, integrate and critically evaluate how both biological processes and concepts and factors from outside of ecology are linked to specified global environmental problems.
Educational Aims
• Provide students with an advanced understanding of biological diversity, its structure, dynamics and responses to environmental change.

• Develop in students an integrated and general understanding of the critical concepts and biological processes in ecology and their interplay with evolution, behaviour and organism form and function.

• Enable students to recognise global problems that have ecological dimensions and to understand how and to what extent ecology can contribute solutions to these issues.

• Develop in students the ability to critically evaluate and synthesise evidence within and beyond the field of ecology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
We are facing an ecological crisis that threatens biological diversity and undermines the life-support system—the many essential ecological goods and services—provided to us by nature. This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure of biodiversity, and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis. Content will be delivered via lectures, structured discussions and debates, and workshops and assessed by extended writing. Assessment will involve two assignments, the first based on critically evaluating the role of ecology in understanding and addressing global environmental problems and the second involving evaluation of how different biological concepts and processes (including those from within and beyond ecology) are relevant to particular global environmental problems.
Outline Syllabus
This module will build on teaching in ecology given in the first year (core modules and first year field course), and introduced through the Zoology Programme content delivered in year 2 semester 1. This module will cover five topics in advanced ecology. These will be selected from the following list depending on the availability of staff to teach them:

Topic 1: How do metapopulation structure and landscape configuration shape species’ responses to climate change?

Topic 2: The ecology of infectious disease: concepts and models to understand and control the spread of disease in natural populations of animals and plants

Topic 3: Macro-ecology and the global distribution of biodiversity

Topic 4: Functional ecology and environmental change: understanding how traits shape species’ ecological strategy, their responses to the environment and ecosystem processes and services

Topic 5: Understanding and predicting the impacts of invasive alien species

Topic 6: Ecological complexity and the maintenance of stable and sustainable ecosystems

Topic 7: Agro-ecology for sustainable and regenerative food production

Topic 8: Community genetics: the ecological consequences of intraspecific variation for community structure and ecosystem functioning

Each topic will be taxonomically broad and will include detail of ecological concepts, theory and mathematical principles relevant to a specific environmental issue or problem. The topics will also be supported by accompanying AO learning materials designed to increase the depth of coverage or briefly cover basic ecological background not elsewhere represented in the programme.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas

Students will be expected to engage fully with all contact-based and directed learning resources, but also engage in self-directed learning to broaden their understanding of the teaching material and to find published literature relevant to the topics and assignments that are not presented in the teaching materials themselves.

As required, students will need to prepare for discussion/ debate sessions and for groupwork through directed and independent learning (reading, asynchronous learning materials, independent study).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. In a typical week learning activities will be centred around lecture-based content, with asynchronous learning, debates, discussions or computer labs developing and extending the lecture-based content. In each two-week topic block there will be 5 hours of lectures, 1 hour of either structured discussion, debate or computer practical, 2-hours of unscheduled e-lectures or other structured self-learning tasks and 16 hours of self-directed learning. A further 14 hours self-directed learning and 16 hours group working will take place across two semester weeks associated with preparation for assessments.

Teaching methods: Lectures (25 hours)

Description: Interactive research-led lectures and seminars covering background and theory on key advanced topics in ecology and the relationships to current global environmental problems
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-outs discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A. Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Seminars (3 hours)

Description: Seminars will take the form of structured discussions and debates. Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics in ecology or topic-relevant ecological papers and reports, with a focus on developing skills in argument construction and critical analysis and synthesis of evidence
Each topic will provide at least one opportunity for students to gain experience in discussing advanced ecology in groups or individually, supported by preparation through reading/ asynchronous online learning tasks or data handling, building confidence in the students. Staff-led and student-led discussion will form the basis of these group sessions fostering critical thinking and confidence. The sessions will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore a greater breadth of issues, and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of different biological and non-biological factors influencing global environmental problems. Attendance will be monitored.
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Practical (2 hours)

Description: Computer workshops. Data manipulation/ modelling practicals designed to reinforce understanding of mathematical models that can be applied to understand and predict dynamic interactions within and between species
Computer workshops enhance digital fluency, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: E-lectures (unscheduled; 10 hours)

Description: Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material, learning tasks, or structured reading provided to broaden topic understanding and stimulate independent study
This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for contact sessions (lectures and discussions), and that adds value to independent study time, leading to a greater depth and breadth of learning. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. This material includes recommended reading (from texts and peer reviewed literature), structured reading (guided literature searching/ reading with specific goals linked to contact sessions), links to external video or web copy, theoretical background, reflection and critical assessment tasks based around lectures and discussions. (Confidence; Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement monitored in contact sessions.

Teaching methods: Group work (16 hours)

Description: Small group work to prepare and submit the integrative ecology assignment. Working in small groups is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches, and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Groupwork also promotes skills in team-based working and collaboration that are highly sought after in the workplace.
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement and contribution monitored through peer assessment.

Teaching methods: Self-directed learning (94 hours)

Description: Consolidation of taught material; preparation for taught sessions, discussions, debates and computer practicals; literature review, evaluation and synthesis to support taught sessions and assignments.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Two summative assessments (coursework), one in the middle of S1 and one at end of course:

i) Ecological solutions assignment (70% weighting): A critical evaluation of the role of ecology in understanding and addressing/ solving a specified major global environmental problem or issue (based on one of the module topics chosen each year by teaching staff; different topic each year). Students will review the state-of-the-art for the specified topic in ecology, drawing on teaching materials and independent study, and will discuss how it has informed our understanding of, and provided solutions for, a specific environmental problem. They will also critically evaluate the extent to which this ecological knowledge has made a real-world difference, and any limitations to progress arising from knowledge gaps.

ii) Integrative ecology assignment (30% weighting, groupwork). This assignment will challenge students to contrast, synthesise and critically evaluate learning from this module with relevant teaching content developed outside this module (e.g. relating to evolutionary biology, conservation biology, behaviour, physiology, organismal form and function etc). The assignment will be based on 3 of the topics/ environmental problems covered in the module. For each, the students will review, critically evaluate and synthesise how both ecological and non-ecological concepts and processes are relevant to shaping biotic responses to/ or the development of the environmental problem. The linked processes/ concepts could include any from evolution, behaviour, conservation, genetics, physiology, etc for which there is an evidence base, and to do this the students will need to draw on teaching/learning from this module, from common Y1 modules, from the pre-requisite module(s) and from their independent learning.

Both assignments are highly authentic and research-connected and reflect real-world problems to which an understanding of ecology can contribute strongly. The skills for completion are taught through active learning developed within discussion sessions and debates and through asynchronous online learning tasks and independent learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Both assignments emphasise higher level learning skills that are highly sought after by employers, including critical evaluation, problem solving, literature synthesis, conceptual synthesis, and emphasise digital fluency (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Although formal formative assessment will not be used in this module, the students will receive feedback on their understanding of the content from teaching staff and peers, through discussion sessions and debates and groupwork.

Assessment will take place on the CANVAS VLE for both assignments, using rubrics tailored from current standard rubrics for scientific reports. For the Integrative Ecology assignment, students will complete a Peer Assessment, which will be used to weight each student's marks by their contributions to the groupwork.

A Resit opportunity exists. Reassessment will use the same format but the topic (or topic set) or data will differ. In the case of the Integrative Ecology assignment, if there is only one resitting student, they will have the opportunity to review and discuss their plans for the assignment with one of the teaching team, to get feedback, to ensure they are not placed at a disadvantage, relative to a student group. Reassessment marks will be capped at 40%. Reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate how fundamental ecological concepts, processes and mathematical principles explain/shape the structure and dynamics of populations, communities and ecosystems, at a range of spatial and trophic scales.
 LO2 Critically analyse and synthesize the contributions that ecology makes to understanding, predicting and mitigating global environmental problems.
 LO3 Critically evaluate how different biological and non-biological factors and processes impinge on global environmental problems, using an evidence-based and integrative approach.
 LO4 Synthesise and critically evaluate a range of information, concepts and processes relevant to key ecological problems from this module, life sciences core teaching modules and pre-requisite modules.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed (i) through the use of evidence-based reasoning in classroom discussions and debates focussed on module topics, (ii) through critical evaluation of the uses of ecology in solving real-world problems and (iii) through reflection on the extent to which the literature reach consensus over optimal approaches to solve ecological problems (or indicate knowledge gaps).
 S2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions and debates, groupwork, and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 S3 Teamwork—This skill will be developed through preparation for discussion sessions in groups and for planning and carrying out the integrative ecology assignment (groupwork).
 S4 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their understanding of advanced ecological topics and the ways in which peer discussion/ debate alters this and ii) feedback given during discussion sessions and following AO learning tasks as appropriate.
 S5 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed using data-based learning activities and computer labs (for any topic that requires this).
 S6 Evidence based reasoning—This will be developed in students first through discussion and debate seminars (and linked AO learning tasks) and subsequently through evidence synthesis and critical evaluation of the use of advanced ecology to solve global environmental problems.
 S7 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through an advanced understanding of the ways in which ecology can be used to solve environmental problems and the review and critical evaluation of this application of ecological theory.
 S8 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the module topics for discussions, debates, learning tasks and assignments. This skill will be evident (and assessed) through assignments.
 S9 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the (i) the need to efficiently review and synthesise areas of the scientific literature using online databases (ii) through the handling and analysis of data for topics requiring data-based asynchronous learning tasks, and using software to create diagrams to communicate conceptual or review-based information.
 S10 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be fostered through assignments that require the review, critical evaluation and synthesis of information from the ecological literature and related relevant fields.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2026, starting with year 3.

Overview

Overview
This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure and dynamics of biodiversity and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis.

Teaching will be delivered in a series of two-week blocks that each cover a fundamental topic in ecology and introduce linked real-world problems whose solutions are grounded in ecology (30 contact hours). Each topic will be taught over two weeks, and will comprise, as a minimum, six hours of contact time including five research connected and interactive lectures and one discussion / debate or campus-based field teaching / computer lab. Many topics will have associated asynchronous material (lecture or active learning content) to broaden topic understanding and structure independent study.

Two module assessments (one of these groupwork) are designed to test:

(i) depth of understanding of key advanced topics in ecology,
(ii) critical evaluation of the role of ecology in providing solutions to environmental problems, and
(iii) the ability to synthesise, integrate and critically evaluate how both biological processes and concepts and factors from outside of ecology are linked to specified global environmental problems.
Educational Aims
• Provide students with an advanced understanding of biological diversity, its structure, dynamics and responses to environmental change.

• Develop in students an integrated and general understanding of the critical concepts and biological processes in ecology and their interplay with evolution, behaviour and organism form and function.

• Enable students to recognise global problems that have ecological dimensions and to understand how and to what extent ecology can contribute solutions to these issues.

• Develop in students the ability to critically evaluate and synthesise evidence within and beyond the field of ecology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
We are facing an ecological crisis that threatens biological diversity and undermines the life-support system—the many essential ecological goods and services—provided to us by nature. This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure of biodiversity, and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis. Content will be delivered via lectures, structured discussions and debates, and workshops and assessed by extended writing. Assessment will involve two assignments, the first based on critically evaluating the role of ecology in understanding and addressing global environmental problems and the second involving evaluation of how different biological concepts and processes (including those from within and beyond ecology) are relevant to particular global environmental problems.
Outline Syllabus
This module will build on teaching in ecology given in the first year (core modules and first year field course), and introduced through the Zoology Programme content delivered in year 2 semester 1. This module will cover five topics in advanced ecology. These will be selected from the following list depending on the availability of staff to teach them:

Topic 1: How do metapopulation structure and landscape configuration shape species’ responses to climate change?

Topic 2: The ecology of infectious disease: concepts and models to understand and control the spread of disease in natural populations of animals and plants

Topic 3: Macro-ecology and the global distribution of biodiversity

Topic 4: Functional ecology and environmental change: understanding how traits shape species’ ecological strategy, their responses to the environment and ecosystem processes and services

Topic 5: Understanding and predicting the impacts of invasive alien species

Topic 6: Ecological complexity and the maintenance of stable and sustainable ecosystems

Topic 7: Agro-ecology for sustainable and regenerative food production

Topic 8: Community genetics: the ecological consequences of intraspecific variation for community structure and ecosystem functioning

Each topic will be taxonomically broad and will include detail of ecological concepts, theory and mathematical principles relevant to a specific environmental issue or problem. The topics will also be supported by accompanying AO learning materials designed to increase the depth of coverage or briefly cover basic ecological background not elsewhere represented in the programme.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas

Students will be expected to engage fully with all contact-based and directed learning resources, but also engage in self-directed learning to broaden their understanding of the teaching material and to find published literature relevant to the topics and assignments that are not presented in the teaching materials themselves.

As required, students will need to prepare for discussion/ debate sessions and for groupwork through directed and independent learning (reading, asynchronous learning materials, independent study).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. In a typical week learning activities will be centred around lecture-based content, with asynchronous learning, debates, discussions or computer labs developing and extending the lecture-based content. In each two-week topic block there will be 5 hours of lectures, 1 hour of either structured discussion, debate or computer practical, 2-hours of unscheduled e-lectures or other structured self-learning tasks and 16 hours of self-directed learning. A further 14 hours self-directed learning and 16 hours group working will take place across two semester weeks associated with preparation for assessments.

Teaching methods: Lectures (25 hours)

Description: Interactive research-led lectures and seminars covering background and theory on key advanced topics in ecology and the relationships to current global environmental problems
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-outs discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A. Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Seminars (3 hours)

Description: Seminars will take the form of structured discussions and debates. Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics in ecology or topic-relevant ecological papers and reports, with a focus on developing skills in argument construction and critical analysis and synthesis of evidence
Each topic will provide at least one opportunity for students to gain experience in discussing advanced ecology in groups or individually, supported by preparation through reading/ asynchronous online learning tasks or data handling, building confidence in the students. Staff-led and student-led discussion will form the basis of these group sessions fostering critical thinking and confidence. The sessions will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore a greater breadth of issues, and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of different biological and non-biological factors influencing global environmental problems. Attendance will be monitored.
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Practical (2 hours)

Description: Computer workshops. Data manipulation/ modelling practicals designed to reinforce understanding of mathematical models that can be applied to understand and predict dynamic interactions within and between species
Computer workshops enhance digital fluency, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: E-lectures (unscheduled; 10 hours)

Description: Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material, learning tasks, or structured reading provided to broaden topic understanding and stimulate independent study
This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for contact sessions (lectures and discussions), and that adds value to independent study time, leading to a greater depth and breadth of learning. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. This material includes recommended reading (from texts and peer reviewed literature), structured reading (guided literature searching/ reading with specific goals linked to contact sessions), links to external video or web copy, theoretical background, reflection and critical assessment tasks based around lectures and discussions. (Confidence; Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement monitored in contact sessions.

Teaching methods: Group work (16 hours)

Description: Small group work to prepare and submit the integrative ecology assignment. Working in small groups is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches, and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Groupwork also promotes skills in team-based working and collaboration that are highly sought after in the workplace.
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement and contribution monitored through peer assessment.

Teaching methods: Self-directed learning (94 hours)

Description: Consolidation of taught material; preparation for taught sessions, discussions, debates and computer practicals; literature review, evaluation and synthesis to support taught sessions and assignments.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Two summative assessments (coursework), one in the middle of S1 and one at end of course:

i) Ecological solutions assignment (70% weighting): A critical evaluation of the role of ecology in understanding and addressing/ solving a specified major global environmental problem or issue (based on one of the module topics chosen each year by teaching staff; different topic each year). Students will review the state-of-the-art for the specified topic in ecology, drawing on teaching materials and independent study, and will discuss how it has informed our understanding of, and provided solutions for, a specific environmental problem. They will also critically evaluate the extent to which this ecological knowledge has made a real-world difference, and any limitations to progress arising from knowledge gaps.

ii) Integrative ecology assignment (30% weighting, groupwork). This assignment will challenge students to contrast, synthesise and critically evaluate learning from this module with relevant teaching content developed outside this module (e.g. relating to evolutionary biology, conservation biology, behaviour, physiology, organismal form and function etc). The assignment will be based on 3 of the topics/ environmental problems covered in the module. For each, the students will review, critically evaluate and synthesise how both ecological and non-ecological concepts and processes are relevant to shaping biotic responses to/ or the development of the environmental problem. The linked processes/ concepts could include any from evolution, behaviour, conservation, genetics, physiology, etc for which there is an evidence base, and to do this the students will need to draw on teaching/learning from this module, from common Y1 modules, from the pre-requisite module(s) and from their independent learning.

Both assignments are highly authentic and research-connected and reflect real-world problems to which an understanding of ecology can contribute strongly. The skills for completion are taught through active learning developed within discussion sessions and debates and through asynchronous online learning tasks and independent learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Both assignments emphasise higher level learning skills that are highly sought after by employers, including critical evaluation, problem solving, literature synthesis, conceptual synthesis, and emphasise digital fluency (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Although formal formative assessment will not be used in this module, the students will receive feedback on their understanding of the content from teaching staff and peers, through discussion sessions and debates and groupwork.

Assessment will take place on the CANVAS VLE for both assignments, using rubrics tailored from current standard rubrics for scientific reports. For the Integrative Ecology assignment, students will complete a Peer Assessment, which will be used to weight each student's marks by their contributions to the groupwork.

A Resit opportunity exists. Reassessment will use the same format but the topic (or topic set) or data will differ. In the case of the Integrative Ecology assignment, if there is only one resitting student, they will have the opportunity to review and discuss their plans for the assignment with one of the teaching team, to get feedback, to ensure they are not placed at a disadvantage, relative to a student group. Reassessment marks will be capped at 40%. Reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate how fundamental ecological concepts, processes and mathematical principles explain/shape the structure and dynamics of populations, communities and ecosystems, at a range of spatial and trophic scales.
 LO2 Critically analyse and synthesize the contributions that ecology makes to understanding, predicting and mitigating global environmental problems.
 LO3 Critically evaluate how different biological and non-biological factors and processes impinge on global environmental problems, using an evidence-based and integrative approach.
 LO4 Synthesise and critically evaluate a range of information, concepts and processes relevant to key ecological problems from this module, life sciences core teaching modules and pre-requisite modules.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed (i) through the use of evidence-based reasoning in classroom discussions and debates focussed on module topics, (ii) through critical evaluation of the uses of ecology in solving real-world problems and (iii) through reflection on the extent to which the literature reach consensus over optimal approaches to solve ecological problems (or indicate knowledge gaps).
 S2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions and debates, groupwork, and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 S3 Teamwork—This skill will be developed through preparation for discussion sessions in groups and for planning and carrying out the integrative ecology assignment (groupwork).
 S4 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their understanding of advanced ecological topics and the ways in which peer discussion/ debate alters this and ii) feedback given during discussion sessions and following AO learning tasks as appropriate.
 S5 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed using data-based learning activities and computer labs (for any topic that requires this).
 S6 Evidence based reasoning—This will be developed in students first through discussion and debate seminars (and linked AO learning tasks) and subsequently through evidence synthesis and critical evaluation of the use of advanced ecology to solve global environmental problems.
 S7 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through an advanced understanding of the ways in which ecology can be used to solve environmental problems and the review and critical evaluation of this application of ecological theory.
 S8 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the module topics for discussions, debates, learning tasks and assignments. This skill will be evident (and assessed) through assignments.
 S9 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the (i) the need to efficiently review and synthesise areas of the scientific literature using online databases (ii) through the handling and analysis of data for topics requiring data-based asynchronous learning tasks, and using software to create diagrams to communicate conceptual or review-based information.
 S10 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be fostered through assignments that require the review, critical evaluation and synthesis of information from the ecological literature and related relevant fields.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2026, starting with year 3.

Overview

Overview
This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure and dynamics of biodiversity and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis.

Teaching will be delivered in a series of two-week blocks that each cover a fundamental topic in ecology and introduce linked real-world problems whose solutions are grounded in ecology (30 contact hours). Each topic will be taught over two weeks, and will comprise, as a minimum, six hours of contact time including five research connected and interactive lectures and one discussion / debate or campus-based field teaching / computer lab. Many topics will have associated asynchronous material (lecture or active learning content) to broaden topic understanding and structure independent study.

Two module assessments (one of these groupwork) are designed to test:

(i) depth of understanding of key advanced topics in ecology,
(ii) critical evaluation of the role of ecology in providing solutions to environmental problems, and
(iii) the ability to synthesise, integrate and critically evaluate how both biological processes and concepts and factors from outside of ecology are linked to specified global environmental problems.
Educational Aims
• Provide students with an advanced understanding of biological diversity, its structure, dynamics and responses to environmental change.

• Develop in students an integrated and general understanding of the critical concepts and biological processes in ecology and their interplay with evolution, behaviour and organism form and function.

• Enable students to recognise global problems that have ecological dimensions and to understand how and to what extent ecology can contribute solutions to these issues.

• Develop in students the ability to critically evaluate and synthesise evidence within and beyond the field of ecology.
Marketing Module Synopsis
We are facing an ecological crisis that threatens biological diversity and undermines the life-support system—the many essential ecological goods and services—provided to us by nature. This module will give an advanced-level treatment of the fundamental concepts and principles of the science of ecology that underpin our understanding of the natural world, the structure of biodiversity, and its responses to environmental change. A case-study / problem-based approach will be used to exemplify how an understanding of ecology is critical to predicting and mitigating the impacts of global environmental change, and in resolving the current ecological crisis. Content will be delivered via lectures, structured discussions and debates, and workshops and assessed by extended writing. Assessment will involve two assignments, the first based on critically evaluating the role of ecology in understanding and addressing global environmental problems and the second involving evaluation of how different biological concepts and processes (including those from within and beyond ecology) are relevant to particular global environmental problems.
Outline Syllabus
This module will build on teaching in ecology given in the first year (core modules and first year field course), and introduced through the Zoology Programme content delivered in year 2 semester 1. This module will cover five topics in advanced ecology. These will be selected from the following list depending on the availability of staff to teach them:

Topic 1: How do metapopulation structure and landscape configuration shape species’ responses to climate change?

Topic 2: The ecology of infectious disease: concepts and models to understand and control the spread of disease in natural populations of animals and plants

Topic 3: Macro-ecology and the global distribution of biodiversity

Topic 4: Functional ecology and environmental change: understanding how traits shape species’ ecological strategy, their responses to the environment and ecosystem processes and services

Topic 5: Understanding and predicting the impacts of invasive alien species

Topic 6: Ecological complexity and the maintenance of stable and sustainable ecosystems

Topic 7: Agro-ecology for sustainable and regenerative food production

Topic 8: Community genetics: the ecological consequences of intraspecific variation for community structure and ecosystem functioning

Each topic will be taxonomically broad and will include detail of ecological concepts, theory and mathematical principles relevant to a specific environmental issue or problem. The topics will also be supported by accompanying AO learning materials designed to increase the depth of coverage or briefly cover basic ecological background not elsewhere represented in the programme.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will be accessible through Canvas

Students will be expected to engage fully with all contact-based and directed learning resources, but also engage in self-directed learning to broaden their understanding of the teaching material and to find published literature relevant to the topics and assignments that are not presented in the teaching materials themselves.

As required, students will need to prepare for discussion/ debate sessions and for groupwork through directed and independent learning (reading, asynchronous learning materials, independent study).
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching and learning on this module are delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research connected teaching – Liverpool Curriculum Hallmark). The learning activities are constructively aligned to the programme learning outcomes and assessments. Students develop into independent learners, with critical thinking, reflection, and problem-solving skills. In a typical week learning activities will be centred around lecture-based content, with asynchronous learning, debates, discussions or computer labs developing and extending the lecture-based content. In each two-week topic block there will be 5 hours of lectures, 1 hour of either structured discussion, debate or computer practical, 2-hours of unscheduled e-lectures or other structured self-learning tasks and 16 hours of self-directed learning. A further 14 hours self-directed learning and 16 hours group working will take place across two semester weeks associated with preparation for assessments.

Teaching methods: Lectures (25 hours)

Description: Interactive research-led lectures and seminars covering background and theory on key advanced topics in ecology and the relationships to current global environmental problems
All lecture content will be enriched with opportunities for active learning including small-group break-outs discussions, problem solving tasks, polls, and Q & A. Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Seminars (3 hours)

Description: Seminars will take the form of structured discussions and debates. Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics in ecology or topic-relevant ecological papers and reports, with a focus on developing skills in argument construction and critical analysis and synthesis of evidence
Each topic will provide at least one opportunity for students to gain experience in discussing advanced ecology in groups or individually, supported by preparation through reading/ asynchronous online learning tasks or data handling, building confidence in the students. Staff-led and student-led discussion will form the basis of these group sessions fostering critical thinking and confidence. The sessions will provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore a greater breadth of issues, and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives. Integration of knowledge and content will emerge from discussion of different biological and non-biological factors influencing global environmental problems. Attendance will be monitored.
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: Practical (2 hours)

Description: Computer workshops. Data manipulation/ modelling practicals designed to reinforce understanding of mathematical models that can be applied to understand and predict dynamic interactions within and between species
Computer workshops enhance digital fluency, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. (Digital fluency, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: Yes.

Teaching methods: E-lectures (unscheduled; 10 hours)

Description: Asynchronous recorded lecture/ active learning material, learning tasks, or structured reading provided to broaden topic understanding and stimulate independent study
This is an inclusive approach that allows students to prepare in advance for contact sessions (lectures and discussions), and that adds value to independent study time, leading to a greater depth and breadth of learning. This increases confidence and allows time to reflect, anticipate difficulties and ask questions (asynchronously) before the session itself. This material includes recommended reading (from texts and peer reviewed literature), structured reading (guided literature searching/ reading with specific goals linked to contact sessions), links to external video or web copy, theoretical background, reflection and critical assessment tasks based around lectures and discussions. (Confidence; Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework)
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement monitored in contact sessions.

Teaching methods: Group work (16 hours)

Description: Small group work to prepare and submit the integrative ecology assignment. Working in small groups is an inclusive approach - it increases student confidence by allowing them to discuss ideas and approaches, and uses the diversity of the student cohort to enhance cross cultural understanding: this fosters respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship; Confidence, Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Groupwork also promotes skills in team-based working and collaboration that are highly sought after in the workplace.
Attendance monitored: No, but engagement and contribution monitored through peer assessment.

Teaching methods: Self-directed learning (94 hours)

Description: Consolidation of taught material; preparation for taught sessions, discussions, debates and computer practicals; literature review, evaluation and synthesis to support taught sessions and assignments.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Two summative assessments (coursework), one in the middle of S1 and one at end of course:

i) Ecological solutions assignment (70% weighting): A critical evaluation of the role of ecology in understanding and addressing/ solving a specified major global environmental problem or issue (based on one of the module topics chosen each year by teaching staff; different topic each year). Students will review the state-of-the-art for the specified topic in ecology, drawing on teaching materials and independent study, and will discuss how it has informed our understanding of, and provided solutions for, a specific environmental problem. They will also critically evaluate the extent to which this ecological knowledge has made a real-world difference, and any limitations to progress arising from knowledge gaps.

ii) Integrative ecology assignment (30% weighting, groupwork). This assignment will challenge students to contrast, synthesise and critically evaluate learning from this module with relevant teaching content developed outside this module (e.g. relating to evolutionary biology, conservation biology, behaviour, physiology, organismal form and function etc). The assignment will be based on 3 of the topics/ environmental problems covered in the module. For each, the students will review, critically evaluate and synthesise how both ecological and non-ecological concepts and processes are relevant to shaping biotic responses to/ or the development of the environmental problem. The linked processes/ concepts could include any from evolution, behaviour, conservation, genetics, physiology, etc for which there is an evidence base, and to do this the students will need to draw on teaching/learning from this module, from common Y1 modules, from the pre-requisite module(s) and from their independent learning.

Both assignments are highly authentic and research-connected and reflect real-world problems to which an understanding of ecology can contribute strongly. The skills for completion are taught through active learning developed within discussion sessions and debates and through asynchronous online learning tasks and independent learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Both assignments emphasise higher level learning skills that are highly sought after by employers, including critical evaluation, problem solving, literature synthesis, conceptual synthesis, and emphasise digital fluency (Digital fluency, Active learning; Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Although formal formative assessment will not be used in this module, the students will receive feedback on their understanding of the content from teaching staff and peers, through discussion sessions and debates and groupwork.

Assessment will take place on the CANVAS VLE for both assignments, using rubrics tailored from current standard rubrics for scientific reports. For the Integrative Ecology assignment, students will complete a Peer Assessment, which will be used to weight each student's marks by their contributions to the groupwork.

A Resit opportunity exists. Reassessment will use the same format but the topic (or topic set) or data will differ. In the case of the Integrative Ecology assignment, if there is only one resitting student, they will have the opportunity to review and discuss their plans for the assignment with one of the teaching team, to get feedback, to ensure they are not placed at a disadvantage, relative to a student group. Reassessment marks will be capped at 40%. Reassessment will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO2 Critically analyse and synthesize the contributions that ecology makes to understanding, predicting and mitigating global environmental problems.
 LO3 Critically evaluate how different biological and non-biological factors and processes impinge on global environmental problems, using an evidence-based and integrative approach.
 LO4 Synthesise and critically evaluate a range of information, concepts and processes relevant to key ecological problems from this module, life sciences core teaching modules and pre-requisite modules.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Critical thinking and problem solving—This skill will be developed (i) through the use of evidence-based reasoning in classroom discussions and debates focussed on module topics, (ii) through critical evaluation of the uses of ecology in solving real-world problems and (iii) through reflection on the extent to which the literature reach consensus over optimal approaches to solve ecological problems (or indicate knowledge gaps).
 S2 Verbal and written communication—Students will have opportunities to develop written and oral communication skills through group discussions and debates, groupwork, and written assessments. In addition, this skill will be developed through an understanding of the constituent elements of strong arguments, and exercises in the deconstruction of the student's own arguments, as well as scholarly arguments within research papers.
 S3 Teamwork—This skill will be developed through preparation for discussion sessions in groups and for planning and carrying out the integrative ecology assignment (groupwork).
 S4 Improving own learning/performance - Reflective practice—Students will have opportunities to improve their learning and performance through reflection on (i) their understanding of advanced ecological topics and the ways in which peer discussion/ debate alters this and ii) feedback given during discussion sessions and following AO learning tasks as appropriate.
 S5 Comprehend and use data effectively—This skill will be developed using data-based learning activities and computer labs (for any topic that requires this).
 S6 Evidence based reasoning—This will be developed in students first through discussion and debate seminars (and linked AO learning tasks) and subsequently through evidence synthesis and critical evaluation of the use of advanced ecology to solve global environmental problems.
 S7 Solving problems in a systematic and creative manner—This skill will be developed in students through an advanced understanding of the ways in which ecology can be used to solve environmental problems and the review and critical evaluation of this application of ecological theory.
 S8 Independent-learning—This skill will be developed in students through their self-directed reading on the topics of the module, and through researching the module topics for discussions, debates, learning tasks and assignments. This skill will be evident (and assessed) through assignments.
 S9 Digital skills—This broad set of skills will be developed through the (i) the need to efficiently review and synthesise areas of the scientific literature using online databases (ii) through the handling and analysis of data for topics requiring data-based asynchronous learning tasks, and using software to create diagrams to communicate conceptual or review-based information.
 S10 Information retrieval and review—This skill will be fostered through assignments that require the review, critical evaluation and synthesis of information from the ecological literature and related relevant fields.
